posts.title: MESSAGE FROM UNIVERSITY LIBRARIAN JOHN UNSWORTH
posts.title_plain: MESSAGE FROM UNIVERSITY LIBRARIAN JOHN UNSWORTH
posts.content:
This past summer, I joined the University of Virginia as University Librarian and Dean of Libraries, and Professor of English. This is my third stint at UVA, having received my Ph.D. in English here in 1988, and having served as the first director of the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities (and as a faculty member in the English department) from 1993-2003. I am very glad to be back, and to have returned at a pivotal moment for the University libraries.

There’s much that needs to be discussed and planned with the faculty, including the renovation of Alderman Library, new Library services for the 21st century, new forms of collaboration with librarians in teaching and research, and your priorities for the future development of our collections. Happily, we have just been granted some Strategic Investment Funds to underwrite those discussions, under the rubric of developing a strategic plan for the Library. I plan to use these funds to create an inclusive and thoughtful engagement with faculty and students, broad enough in scope to ensure that the different needs and interests of the Library’s many constituencies are fully represented, and deep enough to produce ideas that, once implemented, will stand the test of time. As we commence this planning process, I will be inviting you to participate in a variety of forums and discussions, and I’ll do my best to make sure that these happen at a variety of times and in a variety of media, so that no one’s participating is precluded by teaching schedules, research commitments, or travel. I hope that you will join the conversation.

Finally, I’m aware that the reorganization of the Library that immediately preceded my arrival may have broken some long-standing channels of faculty-Library communication, and so I’d be grateful if you would let me know of such disconnects when you experience them—just drop an email to unsworth@virginia.edu, and let me know what’s not working, and how it used to work.

posts.title: NEW ONLINE RESEARCH TOOLS
posts.content:
In summer 2016 the Library added a wealth of new online resources for researchers to the Library’s database collection. Old favorites were updated, while new databases were added that cover a variety of disciplines, transcend disciplines, and in some cases defy easy categorization.

From the Papers of the NAACP, Part 18. Special Subjects, 1940-1955

In African-American studies the Library completed the 30-part collection of the Papers of the NAACP, adding parts 3–6, which focus on the organization’s battle for educational equality, voting rights, and integration in housing, as well as the legal defense of nine defendants falsely accused of rape in the 1931 Scottsboro case. In science, the SPIE Digital Library offers the most comprehensive online collection of optics and photonics research, making available nearly half a million technical papers from SPIE Journals and Conference Proceedings published since 1962. The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy offers researchers a dynamic reference work—an evolving encyclopedia, updated regularly by experts to maintain academic standards while “adapting in response to new research.”

Researchers studying English history now have access to Part 3 of the State Papers Online, 1509–1714, covering England under the Stuarts. Scholarly essays provide historical background on affairs of state from James I to the Civil Wars, from the Glorious Revolution to the reign of Queen Anne. Links in the essays direct researchers to calendars of state papers that were condensed and published in the 19th and 20th centuries, as well as high quality scans of the original documents, allowing side-by-side comparison and the option to bookmark and download them as PDFs. British Periodicals 1-2 picks up Britain’s story late in the 17th century and carries it into the early 20th with facsimiles of 472 periodical and journal titles covering the arts, literature, philosophy, music, drama, and architecture, to create a comprehensive social and cultural record of a nation from the Age of Reason through the Industrial Revolution and into the early 20th century.

 

“Reading Room”—from the Visual Resources section of Mass Observation.

England in the mid-20th century is the subject of Mass Observation Online. Beginning in 1937 the Mass Observation Society armed ordinary volunteers with diaries and questionnaires and asked them to go forth and record whatever was going on around them. They recorded opinions about dancing, jazz, movies, television, fashion, politics, the Nazi blitz, race, class, dreams, propaganda, attitudes about sex, conversations taken down in pubs, churches, dance halls, and cinemas, and more. Altogether, the eclectic collection comprises a unique perspective on England’s popular culture in the years before, during, and after WWII.

Researchers for Mass Observation did not have Sage Research Methods, but UVA does. SAGE’s research methods library contains a vast array of reference works, articles, and videos on how to conduct research in the social sciences. Most exciting are the videos, which range from straight lectures to informally presented responses by practitioners. A video might be a spoken definition of a term, lasting only a few seconds, or a long conversation about pros and cons of methodology, like this conversation on What is Oral History Interviewing? The viewer can follow along on a searchable transcript and download a PDF if desired.

These are only a few of the Library’s many new resources. Browse the complete list of new databases, and if you can’t find what you’re looking for, Ask A Librarian.

posts.title: LIBRARY AND ARTS & SCIENCES PILOT “LIBRARY RESEARCH INTENSIVE” COURSES
posts.title_plain: LIBRARY AND ARTS & SCIENCES PILOT “LIBRARY RESEARCH INTENSIVE” COURSES
posts.content:
This fall, the Library is collaborating with the College of Arts & Sciences on a pilot program to offer Library Research Intensive (LRI) courses. The idea came from faculty on the Universities Libraries Committee, who were looking to expand opportunities for deep collaboration between librarians, teaching faculty, and undergraduate students.

In these LRI courses students work closely with a librarian on an advanced research project, such as a research paper, a critical bibliography, a digital project, or a physical or virtual exhibition. The student electing the LRI option earns one additional credit for the course.

In the pilot phase, 1–3 students per course are taking the LRI option. The LRI pilots taking place this semester are:

  • Tico Braun—HILA 3111: Public Life in Modern Latin America
    (with Miguel Valladares, Latin American Studies liaison librarian)—2 students enrolled

  • Sarah Milov—HIUS 3559: Disco and Disillusion: The United States in the 1970s
    (with Keith Weimer, History liaison librarian)—3 students enrolled

  • John Miller—LATI 4559: Roman Religion and Latin Literature
    (with Lucie Stylianopoulos, Classics liaison librarian)—1 student enrolled

  • Andrea Press—MDST 3000: Theory and Criticism of Media
    (with Erin Pappas, Media Studies liaison librarian)—1 student enrolled

  • Andy Stauffer—ENNC 3240: Victorian Poetry
    (with David Whitesell, Special Collections Curator, and Chris Ruotolo, English liaison librarian)—3 students enrolled

The Barrett Reading Room in the Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library

Details about the exact nature of the project, the selection process for interested students, and the frequency of meetings between faculty, librarian and student are being worked out case-by-case by each faculty/librarian team. Depending on the scope of their project, an LRI student may be referred to other experts within the Library, such as staff in Special Collections or the Scholars’ Lab.

At the end of the semester the impact of the LRI program will be evaluated. If the fall pilot goes well, University Libraries Committee chair John Portmann will recruit faculty for a larger pilot of up to a dozen courses in the spring.

If you have questions or suggestions about the Library Research Intensive program, please contact John Portmann or Chris Ruotolo.

posts.title: Fall 2016
posts.content:
Welcome to the second edition of the UVA Faculty Library Newsletter, a project of the University Libraries Committee that strives to keep faculty up to date on Library resources and trends that will interest them.

This June John Unsworth returned to UVA as University Librarian. John received a Ph.D. in English at UVA in 1988 and served on the faculty from 1993–2003 in the English department, during which time he served as the first director of IATH, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities. As you can read in his letter, John is eager to hear your thoughts on Library spaces and services, as well as the future of faculty collaboration with the Library.

Also of note in this issue is this semester’s pilot of “Library Research Intensive” courses, and a feature on some of the Library’s many new online resources. And check the links at the bottom, including opportunities for faculty to tour the Ivy Stacks facility.

Please share this newsletter with the faculty in your unit(s) and encourage them to sign up to receive future editions. And if you haven’t, sign yourself up! The newsletter is available online, but if you’re subscribed, you’ll receive email notification each time we publish a new issue.

Your comments or questions about the newsletter are welcome. We also welcome your suggestions for topics for future issues—you can contact us at libfacultynews@virginia.edu.

posts.title: THE CHARLOTTESVILLE DAILY PROGRESS (THROUGH 1964) NOW ONLINE
posts.title_plain: THE CHARLOTTESVILLE DAILY PROGRESS (THROUGH 1964) NOW ONLINE
posts.content:
It’s now easier to explore Charlottesville’s perspectives on the Great Depression, WWII, the Cold War, the Civil Rights Movement, and the war in Vietnam, because the University Library—with funding from the Jefferson-Madison Regional Library—has extended its online archive of the Daily Progress, Charlottesville’s main source of print news. Issues from the years 1924–1964 have been scanned from the Library’s microfilm holdings and are now available online and accessible through Virgo.

News of FDR’s death dominates the front page on Friday, April 13, 1945. Updates on WWII and a feature on Thomas Jefferson’s birthplace are also included.

Digitized microfilm of the paper’s earliest years (1893–1923) went online in 2013. Since then, the Library determined that issues for the years 1924–1964 entered the public domain when copyright was not renewed. You can now search through the database in Virgo, clicking individual years, months, and issues. Clicking a link to an issue gives you a thumbnail of the front page. Clicking the thumbnail gets you thumbnails of the entire issue. You can set a “Default Zoom” and scroll through the pages using screen navigation tools or keyboard arrows, or you can click individual thumbnails to download copies up to full-size. You can get to another year, month, or issue by using the “Browse Collection” box on the left side of the main screen. Most of the scans are as clean and readable as you could wish.

The collection offers an opportunity to explore popular culture in advertisements and notices that reveal prevailing attitudes. You can follow changes in the physical environment and track the city’s expansion from year to year. You can see what cars people drove, what movies they saw, and how public transit changed with the times. Browsing a database allows you to take in world events as interpreted through Charlottesville’s eyes. Whatever your primary interests, the Daily Progress Digitized Microfilm is a rich vein of information about the community surrounding Jefferson’s University.

You can read more about the project on the Library’s News & Announcements blog. If you have any questions or comments about using the archive, please use the Virgo Feedback form, or “Ask a Librarian”—especially Barbie Selby.

posts.title: UPDATE ON IVY STACKS EXPANSION AND THE ALDERMAN LIBRARY RENEWAL
posts.title_plain: UPDATE ON IVY STACKS EXPANSION AND THE ALDERMAN LIBRARY RENEWAL
posts.content:
Preliminary discussions continue about renovating Alderman Library. The legislature has now passed House Bill 1344, a capital projects funding bill that covered proposals from many state institutions, including UVA. You can see the full text of the bill here.

Memorial Hall of Alderman Library, 1938.

The bill lists Alderman Renewal as “Renovate Alderman Library, Life Safety Phase I.” It states, “beginning July 1, 2017, the following projects shall be funded for detailed planning. The planning will address fire suppression, egress, and ADA compliance. University Librarian Martha Sites has been meeting with Provost Tom Katsouleas and officials from the University budget and legislative offices to establish a tentative timeline for submitting a plan to the state. Incoming University Librarian John Unsworth will lead the next steps in this project when he arrives at the end of June.

The Ivy Stacks facility currently holds over 1 million volumes.

Related to Alderman is the Ivy Stacks Expansion Project, which will add additional off-site shelving by expanding the existing Ivy Stacks building on Old Ivy Road. This project has University funding and is in the planning stages. It is likely to be an extension of the current facility, with the addition of a reading room. The current building can hold up to two million volumes (a “volume” is anything that takes up shelf space), but it is already 60% full. It receives material from the professional schools’ libraries as well as Special Collections. Work teams from Facilities Management, the Office of the University Architect, the Office of the Provost, and the Library are still reviewing how many volumes the extension will hold. It is anticipated that the building will be completed in late 2017. For questions, contact the Library’s Director of Delivery and Access, Esther Onega.

The Library has held open sessions on the projects, most recently on May 13 when Sites and Katsouleas went over the latest news from the legislature. In that meeting, Katsouleas noted that when the planning begins, he expects the process to be “open, consultative, and iterative” with stakeholders throughout the University represented. The Library, along with the Office of the Provost, will continue to keep the University community informed on these and other facilities projects as new developments arise. There is also an early Alderman Renewal site that includes FAQs and a form to voice your thoughts and ideas. You can also contact Charlotte Morford, Director of External Relations, with any questions about the project.

posts.title: UVA LIBRARY ACQUIRES TITLES FROM SNEAK REVIEWS
posts.title_plain: UVA LIBRARY ACQUIRES TITLES FROM SNEAK REVIEWS
posts.content:
Remember Sneak Reviews? When Charlottesville’s beloved local video store closed in 2015, the Library purchased about 13,000 of Sneak Reviews’ DVDs and Blu-Ray discs. Titles were selected based on a number of parameters, including scarcity, relevance to the curriculum, and appeal to diverse communities. The addition of these videos greatly strengthens the Library’s collection of foreign films, documentaries, and LGBT films; it also fills out many incomplete TV show runs (e.g., in cases where we owned only the first two seasons, we purchased the next three). It will enrich our major release feature films collection and provide some additional copies of our most widely circulating titles.

The collection is currently being processed by Library staff. You can contact Collection Management Librarian Leigh Rockey with questions, and read more about Sneak Reviews and the Library’s acquisition of titles from its collection in the C-VILLE Weekly.

posts.title: LEARN HOW TO USE NEW PROGRAMS AT LYNDA.COM
posts.title_plain: LEARN HOW TO USE NEW PROGRAMS AT LYNDA.COM
posts.content:
Are you interested in a new technology for the classroom or your research, but don’t know where to get started? Then you need Lynda.com! The Library’s institutional subscription to Lynda.com provides free access to thousands of in-depth online video tutorials. Anyone with a UVA computing ID can logon to Lynda.com with NetBadge and begin learning programs like JavaScript, jQuery, Camtasia, Revit, iMovie, Photoshop, Sketchup, Unity, “R”, and many others. Just browsing through Lynda.com’s continually expanding array of video courses might alert you to new technologies that could be of use to you.

Lynda.com is accessible on all computing platforms—PC, MAC, and mobile devices—and lessons are presented by expert instructors in short, discrete bits so users can get just the answers they need. One of the conveniences of Lynda.com is that you decide how much or little instruction you require. It’s great if you are already proficient in a particular program and only need to catch up with the latest upgrade. It’s also perfect if you need to settle in and learn a new program from scratch, step by step at a comfortable pace.

You can get to Lynda.com from the “Research” page on the Library’s website, where it’s listed in the left sidebar under “Popular Links.” You can also get to it from the “Popular Guides” section by clicking “Education”; it’s in the menu at the top of the next screen. See the areas circled in red in the screenshot below. The Research page itself is accessible from anywhere on the Library site via the top navigation bar.

After logging on with NetBadge and furnishing your name and email, you’ll have a Lynda.com account and a vast video library to select from. Mouse over the word “Library” at the top of the page and a dropdown menu lets you survey broad categories of interest (3D + Animation, Business, Design, IT, Photography, Video, Web, etc.), each cross-referenced to a Topic, Software, and Learning Path to guide your study. Click “Library” to get a complete list of subjects. When you click a subject, you’ll see all the available videos, and can narrow choices according to skill level, the list of software courses, or video authors to help choose what will be most useful for you.

New to the University, or otherwise unfamiliar with the library system? Check out other services available to faculty.

posts.title: Summer 2016
posts.content:
Welcome to the first UVA Library Faculty Newsletter! The newsletter is a new project of the University Libraries Committee (ULC), which brings together Library leadership with faculty and student representatives to advise the Provost on matters concerning UVA’s Library system. The University Committees site has more information on the Libraries Committee and its membership.

The newsletter is meant to provide faculty with updates on Library resources and news. It was spearheaded by Associate Professor of Anthropology and ULC member Lise Dobrin, who leads the newsletter working group. If you have ideas for future newsletter content, or any other feedback, please email us at libfacultynews@virginia.edu.

We anticipate releasing 2-3 editions of the Faculty Newsletter a year. You will only receive future newsletters if you subscribe to be notified when they appear. YOU CAN DO SO HERE, or use the “Subscribe” button in the top banner.

There is a lot going on in our library system today. As you may be aware, it was recently announced that John Unsworth will be returning to UVA as the new University Librarian at the end of June. Unsworth will take over from Martha Sites, who has served in an interim role as University Librarian since Karin Wittenborg’s retirement in 2014. Sites joined the Library in 1996 as Associate University Librarian for Information Technology and has been instrumental in shaping the University’s “library of tomorrow” that blends digital and non-digital tools, services, and programs. Prior to that she was Director of User Support in UVA’s central information technology organization. The Library and the ULC are grateful to Martha for her more than 40 years of service to the University.
